thread.title: Seattle Seahawks defense turning into the 'Region of Gloom'
thread.title_full: Seattle Seahawks defense turning into the 'Region of Gloom' | OregonLive.com

author: Geoffrey C. Arnold | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Seattle Seahawks defense turning into the 'Region of Gloom'
text:
The Seattle Seahawks' "Legion of Boom" secondary and defense is threatening to transform into the "Region of Gloom."
The transformation is occurring after a series of performances in which the defense has been unable to close out games. It's a trend of collapses that started during their loss in last season's Super Bowl.
The Seahawks are 2-3 and remain firmly in the playoff hunt in the NFC. However, they are not trending upward. Their wins have come against two teams ( Chicago, Detroit) with a combined record of 2-8. And let's not forget that the win against the Lions was aided and abetted by a missed call by the officials.
The way in which the Seahawks have lost games this season is familiar. They possess a lead late in the game, and the defense can't hold the lead against a pass-happy quarterback.
The Seahawks are allowing an average of 214.2 passing yards a game, 26th in the league. Teams are completing 67.9 percent of their passes against the Seahawks, which ranks 27th in the league. The Seahawks have picked off one pass this season.
During their 27-24 overtime loss at Cincinnati, the Bengals mounted four scoring drives in the fourth quarter and overtime (two touchdowns and two field goals). Cincinnati quarterback Andy Dalton completed 10-of-11 passes and the Bengals offense gained 146 yards in the fourth quarter.
Opponents have targeted cornerback Cary Williams throughout the season. The Seahawks pride themselves on relying on man-to-man coverage, but Williams has struggled and needs help. Interestingly, some teams are also going after strong safety Kam Chancellor. Chancellor is the leader of the defense, but his run support is better than his ability to cover receivers.
Part of the problem is the inconsistent offense. The Seahawks punted on their final six possessions against Cincinnati, the defense spent too much time on the field and tired in the fourth quarter and overtime. That's a good excuse for the loss to Cincinnati, but not so much in the game against winless Detroit and Green Bay.
The Seahawks aren't bullying teams anymore and they need to rediscover the swagger that helped propel them to two consecutive trips to the Super Bowl. They'll get another opportunity to regain that intimidation factor when they host Cam Newton and the unbeaten Carolina Panthers Sunday.
-- Geoffrey C. Arnold | @geoffreyCarnold
